title: [Suggestion] Have champion mastery score influence LP gain/loss
body:
To clarify, I'm referring to your end game mastery score (S, A, B, etc). I think having this would reduce ragers/quiters, as their performance determines their final LP gain/loss (hopefully making them more willing to continue playing in a losing game).

It'd also be nice to be recognized for your performance.

E.g. If you feed the enemy, but you still win game, you probably don't deserve to gain the same amount of LP as the person who carried you. Or if you play really well but end up losing, you don't deserve to lose the same amount of LP as your feeding teammate.

replies.body:
Yeah let's base people's rank in a team game on their individual score.

Logic.

But that's how it's done already.

If I'm on a winning streak and you're on a losing streak, you lose more LP/gain less LP than I do.

Yeah, that's pretty cool. Has pretty much nothing to do with what I said though. I didn't say anything about MMR or winrate, I'm just saying that basing someone's LP gain on their individual score in the scoring system is stupid, because it will be a lot harder for support mains and tank mains to rank up.

I don't think people should get extra LP just because they're playing the same champion over and over again, as it would discourage people from diversifying their champ pool.

It could be good to calculate LP based on individual performance for the reasons that you said, but it might promote an unhealthy environment where people play very selfishly. For example, if LP was influenced by a player's kda, then they would probably focus more on preserving their score than helping out the team.

I'm not referring to your mastery level (i.e. level 7 or whatever). I'm referring to your end game rating (i.e. S, A, B, etc). That's not affected by how many times you play a champ.

And I don't understand what you mean by play selfishly? As in try not to die?

Ok, the title of the discussion said 'champion mastery' so I thought it meant the levels. 

When I say that people play selfishly, I mean that they play the game as if their own score is more important than doing things for the team. Here are some examples of things that are 'selfless':

. Stealing a dragon/baron, taking a tower/inhib, or going for some other objective that may result in your death
. Helping to take down an important enemy or saving an important ally (<--- especially for supports) maybe at the cost of your own life
. Pushing out a lane when necessary, even though it may be risky
. Going to help your teammates, even though you might miss farm or fall a bit behind

Basically, being selfless is doing something that helps others at a cost to yourself (e.g. your kda). By making LP dependent on scores like kda, selfless play is not rewarded at all and overall there is less teamwork.

What I'm trying to say is, game rating is not exactly indicative of how much someone contributed towards a win/loss. I know there isn't a perfect measure of this, but by making LP dependent on more things, it adds stress (e.g. if a win is imminent, people still have to worry about keeping their scores as high as possible and getting good grades rather than just closing out the game).

If a new system were to be implemented, it would be trading the ability to relax in-game for more control over player's rankings. I myself believe the former is more important, but it is up to you to decide.

Here's the thing...if what you are about to do is very risky, i.e. the chances of you dying > the chances of you achieving your goal, it's probably not worth it. Unless your death will result in a net win for the team (e.g. you pooped on the carry, died, and won the teamfight).

Anyway, I don't think this will change how people naturally play a great deal. I think it will help stop people trolling (feeding, etc). And it will help separate those who play consistently well from those who play badly.

For selfish players, the risk doesn't even need to be very high - they are unwilling to do something that would help their team overall if it doesn't provide benefit to their score. You've probably seen those people who keep staying in lane and don't help others, even when asked - that's the kind of each-person-for-themself playing that is not healthy to the team environment. Trolls/feeders can be reported; it is much more difficult for self-centred people. 

Two more things that will be encouraged by a new system: ks'ing and raging when mistakes are made.

I'm not trying to be offensive btw, I have thought about this b4 but it just doesn't work out.

If someone is genuinely a bad player, you can't report them. That's their skill level. So while feeding on purpose can be reported, feeding because you're bad can't be.

We obviously have 2 very different opinions about how the game should be played. If you're normally a calm player (not a rager), I don't see how this system will make you one. 

Unless it's actually trialed then neither of us will know if it works out for the better or not.

Tbh thats kind of a good thing.

As in the lower elos players are far more reckless and just dive in and will happily trade their lives for others.

This is why feeding is so prevalent.

If the entire team played more cautiously it would lessen the rampant feeding seen in such elos leaving only the legitimate trolls.

And in the higher elos players are already extremely cautious anyway so there would be no change.

in other words this would kill two birds with one stone.

Not only would players interested in climbing play better because they now have a motivation to.

it would also quell a vast majority of the "omg my team sucked we had a 1/13 fiora that just kept going in" because if that 1/13 fiora does that she will lose massive ammounts of lp and mmr on the loss thus resulting in her being pushed to the bottom of the ladder much faster.

This would make mmr far more accurate as you would no longer have trash tier players who got lucky a few games in a row and saw an mmr boost because of it and then never lost said mmr because they are bad enough to drag their teams down but not bad enough to lose every game.

and personally i think it should work that way because ranking players based on individual performance rather than teamplay would actually correct mmr much much faster than through teamplay based rankings.

Infact to give an example of just how skewed solo queue is, i have a rather close my heart story of defeating a player by the name of elmo in the top lane in a custom game.

Why is that story close to my heart, because at the time, he was challenger in ranked 5's

Now where am i going with this, well if hes challenger in ranked 5's that means he has impressive teamplay skills, aswell as invidual skill in order to not hold his team down.

So why was he plat 2 in solo queue.

Think about that.

challenger in a mode where he could choose his team and his team was equally as skilled as him.

plat 2 in solo queue, where he had to rng his teams.

like shit man solo queue is SUPPOSED to be about individual skill thats its entire shtick, to say "nah were gonna rank you on nothing more but win/loss ratio without accounting for rng" is kinda stupid.

Because 50% winrate or not, its very possible to suddenly win 20 games in a row by sheer luck, or lose 20 games in a row from sheer luck, and you dont even be the one who caused that, you could feed your ass off and get carried 20 times, or play like a god and get weighed down 20 times.

it just happens, but thats 20 games of mmr loss or gain.

Which then takes another, god upwards of 50-60 games to fix that mmr.

And within those 50-60 games its actually pretty likely that you will either get lucky or unlucky again, thus furthing the innaccuracy even futher.

And its just a never ending cycle until you are a few Hundred to a thousand mmr points above or below your true mmr and thats where the effects start to reverse and yoyo.

But by then the damage is already done because by that point you usually have to win like 50 games in a row, or more just to correct it, or lose said number of games.

Not just 50 games, 50 games in a row, if you lose one you have to win one more to correct that loss and vice versa.


I know im ranting, but its really not a good system.

The only game i have ever seen team based mmr actually work is world of warcraft, and the only reason worked there is they dont have matchmaking for their ranked system, they went out of their way to restrict you to forming your own teams specifically to remove said rng.

And it works, rng is the BANE of mmr because it doesn't equalize like the math would tell you.

Post-game rating is not exactly indicative of how much someone contributed towards a win/loss. People can take objectives, protect their team members, push out lanes, provide vision... so many selfless plays that wouldn't show up in the rating. If rating is included in LP calculations, people are discouraged from putting the welfare of the team before themselves. 

Implementing a gradings-based system also adds unnecessary stress to games - even if a win is very likely, players would focus on keeping their kda's as high as possible, not taking the risks that are necessary to close out the game. If a loss is likely, a person might completely avoid enemies so that they don't risk dying and making their score worse whilst their teammates are left to defend (and are thus unlikely to succeed).

Overall, the current system works in it's own way - a better player would win more on average than a worse one, so they should be ranked higher. Feeders who don't deserve their elo are anomalies, and should not skew other players' rankings in the long run.

Well to be honest the system can always be adapted to include such things.

Also kda =/= high grade, ive played plenty of games where i go something like 30/11/10 and dont get a grade higher than A-.

its alot more intricate than that.

Also your last statement is categorically incorrect.

If that were true players like dyrus would not be currently stuck in diamond while playing at a top 10 challenger level etc etc.

Its 100% about team dynamic not individual skill which unfortunately, makes rng a major factor in determining your mmr.

For instance while being b5 i am not at the bottom of the ladder by any means.

Infact if i was to go on a losing streak right now i could drop more than like 500+ mmr points.

Yet i see the same feeders almost every game.

Because their mmr is yoyoing, instead of diving as it should.

This is purely due to rng, because one game they feed till they lose, the next game they still feed but they get carried which equalizes their mmr and makes everyone elses more inaccurate.

No, it's true, the law of big numbers means that people who help their team win more in soloQ get put higher in the long run.  I mean, if you've played hundreds of games, it hardly makes sense to say that other players have determined your position. As for the examples of pro players that you've stated, some people just perform differently in soloQ than in a professional environment (e.g. their play style might  fit a lot better with the team that they trained with than with people that they don't). But even so, I'm sure that Dyrus won't remain in Diamond after he has played enough games.

And also, grades may be a more comprehensive indicator than kda, but they still don't account for many of the things that someone can do to contribute to a win.

yes in the long run.

By the same laws of probability unless you are atleast 3 divisions below your true mmr its going to take hundreds, if not thousands of games to reach that equilibrium

take myself im at i think 570 games?

most people would think "oh well thats because you are at the mmr you belong in"

But if you analyse my winrate over a long period of time instead of just looking at it at face value its been steadily climbing from the start of the season to now.

With only the occasional dip down that can be attributed to having a few bad games.

infact on average if i recall i go up half a percent every week.

Now my winrate constantly going up inturn means that assuming im playing consistently i am not at my true mmr.

But at the same time, my mmr does not move.

Infact it yoyos, so while my winrate is in a constant upward trend, my mmr is stationary.

I can prove this because im playing the same teammates, that i had in preseason.

I havnt changed elo at all.

This contradicts every single last statement ever made by someone in regards to climbing.

Because the general consensus is 50% winrate means you are where you belong.

And sub 50% means you are higher than you belong.

Which means it should be mathematically impossible for me to have a 47% winrate with an upward trend in winrate while being at the exact same elo i was at when i had a 30% winrate all the while not improving very much at all in skill, infact arguably im playing worse than i did in preseason.

That right there, is proof the math is wrong.

Its correct in the sense of "well if you flip a coin 50 times and have a 50/50 chance to get heads or tails you are more likely to get 25 heads 25 tails than 50 heads" but thats not how it works.

Because there isnt a 50% chance of winning.

The actual math is like this

You have a 50/50 chance of a bad player existing in your game on either team.

You then have a 4/9 chance of said player being on your team

thats a 44.4444 repeating chance for said bad player to be on your team.

So assuming you play 1000 games.

And you you will on average have 500 bad players in your games, and of those 500 bad players 222 bad players.

The enemy team will have 277 bad players

Now once you have those numbers you now have to go with a 50/50 chance again to account for the 50/50 chance that said bad player is so terrible that you cant carry them

This brings the averages down to 111 games lost due to bad players and 138 games won due to bad players.

Now thats an ideal world.

In reality anyone whos played 1000 games of ranked, has encountered FAR FAR more than 500 bad players in their games, on either the enemies team or your own team.

How could that happen?

Well simple, while you are account for your own win/loss rate.

You forgot to do the math for the other 9 players in the game.

That 111 games lost due to a bad player has 50% chance for every game to have been the deciding factor and had that not existed you wouldve won.

so in those 111 games, 55.2 of those games the enemy team did not deserve the win.

In that case assuming you get completely different enemies in each of those games.

Those 55.2 games accounts for 276.2 illegitimate wins for players

Said 276.2 players are now very likely to be the "bad players" in another game since they have had their mmr's artificially raised.

This then increases the chances to get a bad player in that elo to above 50% due to more players that dont belong there existing.

Which in turn creates more illegitimate wins.

etc etc its a knock on effect.

I support this fully, i am a huge proprietor of reducing the ammount of rng in the solo queue system by recognizing individual skill instead of just teamplay.

Since teamplay is heavily luck based when you get placed with 4 random players.

for instance with such a system i personally would have a much easier time climbing as i actually average atleast an A+ if not an S rank.

Which puts me if i recall in the top 10%? of the champions i play, atleast performance wise.
